Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: Do you have my goods still?

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: Did you look inside?

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: I'm not interested in things that don't concern me.

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: I have a friend who has a fine rug. Maybe your wife would like it.

Speaker: vito
Dialogue: We have no money for a rug.

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: No.  He would give it away.  I know how to repay a consideration.

Speaker: vito
Dialogue: She would like it.

Speaker: vito
Dialogue: Your friend lives in a fine building.

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: Oh yes, the very best.

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: Ah, he's not at home.  Oh, well, he wouldn't mind.

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: A little help.

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: Good, you waited for us.

Speaker: tessio
Dialogue: Who is he?

Speaker: augustino
Dialogue: My son, Carmine...it's all right.

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: Paisan Augustino was a gunsmith in the Italian army.  We do each other favors.

Speaker: augustino
Dialogue: My boy is studying the flute.  He plays very well.  He helps me at night so we can buy him a silver flute someday.  Now he has one made of wood.  Carmine...play...play for my friends.

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: Lady, I got a bargain on these dresses.  Five dollars each.  You gotta pay at least fifteen, maybe twenty in a store.  Look at them, first class.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: I don't know which one I like best.

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: You'd look beautiful in all of these.  You should buy at least two.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Are you kidding?  My husband will kill me if he knows I paid five dollars for one dress.

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: You can have two for five.

Speaker: tessio
Dialogue: What took so long?

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: She couldn't decide.

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: Vito, take the rest of the stock over to Dandine's warehouse; he'll move it to a wholesaler.

Speaker: fanucci
Dialogue: Ahhh, young fellow.  People tell me you're rich, you and your two friends.  Yet, you don't show enough respect to send a few dresses to my home.  You know I have three daughters.

Speaker: fanucci
Dialogue: This is my neighborhood.  You and your friends have to show me a little respect, ah?  This truck you hijacked was in my neighborhood. You should let me wet my beak a little.

Speaker: fanucci
Dialogue: I understand each of you cleared around six hundred dollars.  I expect two hundred dollars for my protection and I'll forget the insult.  After all, young people don't know the courtesies due a man like myself.

Speaker: fanucci
Dialogue: Otherwise the police will come to see you and your wife and children will be dishonored and destitute. Of course, if my information as to your gains is incorrect, I'll dip my beak just a little.  Just a little, but no less than one hundred dollars, and don't try to deceive me, eh paisan?

Speaker: vito
Dialogue: My two friends have my share of the money.  I'll have to speak to them after we deliver these to the wholesaler.

Speaker: fanucci
Dialogue: You tell your friends I expect them to let me wet my beak in the same manner.  Don't be afraid to tell them.  Clemenza and I know each other well, he understands these things.  Let yourself be guided by him.  He has more experience in these matters.

Speaker: vito
Dialogue: You must understand, this is all new to me...

Speaker: fanucci
Dialogue: I understand...

Speaker: vito
Dialogue: But thank you for speaking to me as a Godfather.

Speaker: fanucci
Dialogue: You're a good fellow.

Speaker: fanucci
Dialogue: You have respect.  A fine thing in the young.  Next time, speak to me first, eh?  Perhaps I can help you make your plans.

Speaker: tessio
Dialogue: Do you think he'd be satisfied with the two hundred dollars?  I think he would.

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: That scar-faced bastard will find out what we got from the wholesaler. He won't take a dime less than three hundred dollars.

Speaker: tessio
Dialogue: What if we don't pay?

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: You know his friends...real animals. And his connections with the police. Sure he'd like us to tell him our plans so he can set us up for the cops and earn their gratitude. Then they would owe him a favor; that's how he operates.  We'll have to pay.  Three hundred, are we agreed?

Speaker: tessio
Dialogue: What can we do?

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: They say Fanucci has a license from Maranzalla himself to work this neighborhood.

Speaker: vito
Dialogue: If you like, why not give me fifty dollars each to pay Fanucci.  I guarantee he will accept that amount from me.

Speaker: tessio
Dialogue: When Fanucci says two hundred he means two hundred.  You can't talk with him.

Speaker: vito
Dialogue: I'll reason with him.  Leave everything in my hands.  I'll settle this problem to your satisfaction.

Speaker: vito
Dialogue: I never lie to people I've accepted as my friends.  Speak to Fanucci yourself tomorrow.  Let him ask you for the money, but don't pay it, and don't in any way quarrel with him.  Tell him you have to get the money and will send me as your messenger.  Let him understand that you're willing to pay what he asks, don't bargain.  I'll go to his house, and quarrel with him.  He likes me; enjoys explaining how things are here.  He uses ten sentences when he only needs one, so while he talks, I'll kill him.

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: Our driver has drunk too much wine.

Speaker: tessio
Dialogue: He's going to kill Fanucci.

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: Then, after that, what?  Joe 'Little Knife' Pisani; Willie Bufalino, maybe, Mr. Maranzalla himself, c'mon!

Speaker: vito
Dialogue: Fanucci is not connected; he is alone.

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: What?  You read it in the papers?

Speaker: vito
Dialogue: This man informs to the police; this man allows his vengeance to be bought off... No, he is alone.

Speaker: tessio
Dialogue: If you're wrong...

Speaker: vito
Dialogue: If I'm wrong, they will kill me.

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: All three daughters are at church; he is alone.  It's important that you let his neighbors see you leave. Tessio has broken the latch on the skylight of his building.

Speaker: clemenza
Dialogue: See, Brother Carmello, even the church makes numbers.

Speaker: priest
Dialogue: It's only the way we collect that's different.

Speaker: fanucci
Dialogue: I'm right.  Only two hundred dollars.

Speaker: vito
Dialogue: I'm a little short.  I've been out of work.  Let me owe you the money for a few weeks.

Speaker: fanucci
Dialogue: No hard feelings, eh?  If I can ever do you a service let me know. You've done a good job for yourself tonight.

Speaker: fanucci
Dialogue: What's the matter, Signora?  You don't say 'good evening'?

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: 'Good evening,' Signor Fanucci.

Speaker: vito
Dialogue: Santino, your papa loves you.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Can't you sleep?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Are you alright?

Speaker: anthony
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Did you like your party?

Speaker: anthony
Dialogue: I got lots of presents.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Do you like them?

Speaker: anthony
Dialogue: I didn't know the people who gave them to me.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: They were friends.

Speaker: anthony
Dialogue: Did you see my present for you?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: No, where is it?

Speaker: anthony
Dialogue: On your pillow.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I'm leaving very early tomorrow, before you wake up.

Speaker: anthony
Dialogue: I know.  How long will you be gone?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Just a few days.

Speaker: anthony
Dialogue: Will you take me?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I can't.

Speaker: anthony
Dialogue: Why do you have to go?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: To do business.

Speaker: anthony
Dialogue: I can help you.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Some day you will.

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: Michael?  Why are the drapes open?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Go with the kids.

Speaker: rocco
Dialogue: They're still on the property. Maybe you better stay inside.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Keep them alive.

Speaker: rocco
Dialogue: We'll try.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: It's important.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: It will be all right.  We were lucky.

Speaker: rocco
Dialogue: Your family all seem to be okay in the other houses; your Mother's still sleeping.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: And?

Speaker: rocco
Dialogue: No sign of them yet; but they're still on the Estate.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Deanna, will you get back into the house!

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: I'm getting out of here I said; these guys all have guns!

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Fredo, can't you shut that woman up!  Get her in here!

Speaker: deanna
Dialogue: I don't want to stay here...

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Mike, what can I do, she's a hysterical woman...

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: Leave her alone!  You're talking as though she has no right to be frightened when there are machine guns going off in her backyard.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Have Tom Hagen meet me in the Harbor House.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Sit down, Tom.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: There's a lot I can't tell you, Tom. I know that's upset you in the past; and you've felt that it was because of some lack of trust or confidence.  But it is because I do trust you that I've kept so much secret from you.  It's precisely that at this moment, you are the only one that I can completely trust.  In time, you'll understand everything.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: But your people... Neri... Rocco; you don't think...

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: No, I have confidence in their loyalty... but this is life and death, and Tom, you are my brother.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Mikey, I hoped...

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: No Tom, just listen.  All my people are businessmen; their loyalty is based on that.  One thing I learned from my father is to try to think as the people around you think...and on that basis, anything is possible. Fredo has a good heart, but he is weak...and stupid, and stupid people are the most dangerous of all.  I've kept you out of things, Tom, because I've always known that your instincts were legitimate, and I wanted you to know very little of things that would make you an accomplice, for your own protection. I never blamed you for the setbacks the family took under Sonny; I know you were in a position of limited power, and you did your best to advise and caution him.  What I am saying is that now, for how long I do not know, you will be the Don. If what I think has happened is true; I will leave tonight, and absolutely no one will know how to contact me.  And even you are not to try to reach me unless it is absolutely necessary.  I give you complete power: over Neri... Fredo, everyone.  I am trusting you with the lives of my wife and children, and the future of this family, solely resting on your judgment and talent.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: ...But Tom, you must know that I do this only because I believe you are the only one who is capable of taking over for me.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I've prepared this; have had it for over a month.  It won't explain everything; but indicates where I will be, so in a sense, it is my life.  Also, there are three tasks that must be executed immediately.  Pop would have given those to Luca -- You knew Pop as well as anyone, act as though you were him.  It discusses Kay as well; that will be the most difficult.  The men who tried to kill me tonight, will never leave the estate.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Will we...be able to get who ordered it out of them?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I don't think so.  Unless I'm very wrong...they're already dead. Killed by someone inside...very frightened that they botched it. That's why I am going to disappear in a few minutes, and leave everything to you.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: But if you're wrong...

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: If I'm wrong...

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: ...I don't think I'm wrong.  Yes.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Get rid of the bodies.  Tomorrow morning I want a report made to the local police, and paper, that some explosives we keep on the property were accidentally ignited.

Speaker: senator geary
Dialogue: All right, Mr. Hagen, you've got ten minutes.

Speaker: senator geary
Dialogue: ...and the tape will be running.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Actually, I've come with good news; the Corleone family has done you a favor.

Speaker: senator geary
Dialogue: What the hell are you talking about?

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: We know you're a busy man, with plenty of enemies -- we saw the opportunity to do you a favor, and we did.  No strings.

Speaker: senator geary
Dialogue: No strings.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: You know there's a Senate Investigating Committee recently set up; we thought it would be unfortunate if they were to trace anything though-provoking to your name.

Speaker: senator geary
Dialogue: No one can trace anything to me; I pride myself on that.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Do you gamble?

Speaker: senator geary
Dialogue: A little; what's so thought- provoking about that?

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Do you owe markers?

Speaker: senator geary
Dialogue: Maybe two, three thousand dollars.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: The Corleone family has paid them off for you...as an expression of our esteem.

Speaker: senator geary
Dialogue: There's thirty grand worth of paid off markers -- I never owed that much.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Our mistake.  But what does it matter; it was our money.  We don't even expect thanks.

Speaker: senator geary
Dialogue: You paid off thirty grand I never owed.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: We'll keep it quiet; the people who know are trustworthy...the Committee needn't find out.

Speaker: senator geary
Dialogue: And what's the price of their not finding out.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Simple.  Be friendly like us.  Not hostile.

Speaker: senator geary
Dialogue: Thanks...friend.

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: I'm sorry, Mrs. Corleone.  We're not to let you through.

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: I'm going to the market.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: If you could just give us a list, we'll pick up anything you want.

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: Whose orders are these?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Mr. Hagen's, ma'am.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Kay.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: I wanted to explain this myself... I had business in Carson City.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: It's Michael's request...for your safety.  We can send out for anything you need.

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: I'm supposed to stay in my house.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Within the compound will be fine.

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: I was supposed to take the children to New England next week.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: That's off now.

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: I'm going to see my parents.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Kay, Michael didn't tell me a lot; and what he did tell me, I can't repeat.  But the responsibility for you and the kids was the most important thing he left me with.

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: How long does this go on?

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: I don't know.  I'm sorry, Kay...

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: Am I a prisoner?

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: That's not the way we look at it.

Speaker: purser
Dialogue: I'm terribly sorry to disturb you but we have received two telegrams.

Speaker: merle
Dialogue: Well...come in.

Speaker: connie
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: purser
Dialogue: Yes.  One is from our office in New York.  The check that you wrote for your passage has been returned.

Speaker: connie
Dialogue: Can't be...

Speaker: merle
Dialogue: Why don't you wire your bank?

Speaker: purser
Dialogue: The other telegram is from your bank.  Your account has been closed and the company is warned not to extend any credit.

Speaker: connie
Dialogue: I'll take care of it in Naples.

Speaker: purser
Dialogue: The company hopes so.  But for now, we have orders to change your accommodations.

Speaker: connie
Dialogue: That son of a bitch!

Speaker: porter
Dialogue: Mr. Paul?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: porter
Dialogue: You ordered lunch?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Put it right there.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: You'll wait in the car.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: I'm just going to make lunch.  How about a tuna fish sandwich?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Thank you, Mrs. Roth.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: Hyman...HYMAN, your friend is here.  Why don't you go right upstairs, Mr. Paul?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Fine.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: I'll give a yell when lunch is ready.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Sit down, this is almost over.  You follow the baseball games?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Not for a few years.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: I like sporting events -- I really enjoy watching them in the afternoon. One of the things I love about this country.  I loved baseball ever since Arnold Rothstein fixed the World Series of 1919...I heard you had some trouble.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: What a mistake; people behaving like that, with guns.  It was my understanding we left all that behind.  But, let me tell you, the important thing is that you're all right.  Good health is the most important thing; more than success; more than power; more than money.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: The incident of the other night is a nuisance that I can take care of. I came to you because I want nothing to affect our agreement; I wanted to clear everything I'm going to do with you, just in case.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: You're a considerate young man.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: You're a great man, Mr. Roth, I have much to learn from you.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: However I can help you...

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: The Rosato Brothers have performed services for you in the past; I understand that they are under your protection.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: We do favors for each other...

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Technically, they are still under the Clemenza wing of the Corleone Family, now run by Frankie Pentangeli.  After Clemenza died, the Rosatos wanted territory of their own.  Pentangeli refused, and came to me, asking for permission to eliminate them.  I, of course, knew of their relationship with you, and in gratitude for your help with the Tropicana matter, turned him down.  Pentangeli was furious, and paid one hundred and fifty thousand dollars to have me killed. I was lucky and he was stupid. I'll visit him soon.  The important thing is that nothing jeopardize our plans, yours and mine.  This thing of ours, that we will build.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Nothing is more important.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Pentangeli is a dead man; do you object?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: It's always bad for business; but you have no choice.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Then it's done.  I must choose his replacement: it cannot be Rosato.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Of course you must keep control of your family.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Michael, these things are unimportant.  Who should be the manager of a dime store, Joe or Jack?  Unimportant.  You do what you think is right.  You're a young man, and I'm old and sick.  What we do together in the next few months will be history, Michael; it has never been done before.  We will do this historical thing together, and even your Father could never dream it would be possible.  We are bigger than U.S. Steel, you and me... because in America, anything is possible!  But soon I will be dead, and it will all belong to you.

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: My goodness, you'll rupture your eardrums, Hyman.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: Rosato, where's your brother?

Speaker: rosato
Dialogue: Sitting right behind you.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: He don't want to talk?

Speaker: rosato
Dialogue: We worked it all out beforehand.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: Are we going to eat or what?

Speaker: rosato
Dialogue: Sure, on me.  I got Diner's Club.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: Forget it; I'm suddenly without an appetite.  You're making big trouble, Carmine.

Speaker: rosato
Dialogue: You weren't straight with us, Frankie, what else could we do?

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: We could have talked first, saved a lot of running around.

Speaker: rosato
Dialogue: You wasn't listening, you didn't want to talk.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: Don't I look like I'm listening?

Speaker: rosato
Dialogue: We want Brooklyn one hundred percent.  No more taxes to you.  We want to be only loosely connected with your family -- sort of a under-family all of our own.  Then we can act on all internal matters without talking.  Also we want you to inform Michael Corleone that we can deal directly with him.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: I'm a little hungry, maybe I'll order something.  Joe.  And in return for these concessions, what do you do for me?

Speaker: rosato
Dialogue: We will release the hostages, number one.  Number two, we're here for you to count on when you need us.  We're independent, but we're here if you need us.  In general, we'll cooperate with you and your businesses, and you in turn will cooperate with us.  Pari persu.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: Pari Persu; what the fuck is Pari persu...?

Speaker: rosato
Dialogue: My lawyer went over this beforehand.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: What assurances do I have that there will be no more kidnapping, no more hits?

Speaker: rosato
Dialogue: The same assurance we got from you.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: What if I say shove it?

Speaker: rosato
Dialogue: Then Carmine Fucillo and Tony Blue DeRosa will need to be fitted for slabs.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: You want a war?

Speaker: rosato
Dialogue: We got no choice.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: You know if there's a way I'll go to the commission and the commission will side with me.  That puts me and the other New York families against you.

Speaker: rosato
Dialogue: We got friends in the commission.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: I'm talking about Italians!

Speaker: rosato
Dialogue: What about Michael Corleone?

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: He supports me.

Speaker: rosato
Dialogue: Maybe, yes... maybe no.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: You drove old Pete Clemenza to his grave, Carmine; you and your brother.  Turning on him; trouble in his territories -- you and your demands.  I hold you responsible, just as though you shot him in the head.  And I ain't gonna let that go for long!

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: Nobody I hate calls me Five-Angels to my face!

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: What's up?

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: What's this?

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: Michael Corleone.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: One Michael Corleone...Dove?

Speaker: wife
Dialogue: He's in your study.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: Don Corleone, I wish you let me know you was coming.  We could have prepared something for you.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I didn't want you to know I was coming.  You heard what happened in my home?

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: Michael, yes, we was all relieved...

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: In my home!  In the same room where my wife was sleeping; where my children come in their pajamas, and play with their toys.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I want you to help me take my revenge.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: Michael, anything.  What is it I can do for you?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I want you to settle these troubles with the Rosato Brothers.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: I was just going to contact you, Michael; we just had a 'sit-down' - in fact, I just come from there.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I want you to settle on their terms.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: Mike, I don't understand.  Don't ask me to do that.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Trust me; do as I ask.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: It would be the beginning of the end for my family.  How can I keep all my other territories in like if I let two wise-guys stand up and demand this and that, and then give it to them?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Frankie...do you respect me?  Do I have your loyalty?

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: Always... But sometimes I don't understand.  I know I'll never have your kind of brains, in big deals. But Mike, this is a street thing. And Hyman Roth in Miami is behind the Rosato Brothers.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: Then why do you want me to lay down to them?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Frankie, Roth tried to have me killed.  I'm sure it was him, but I don't know yet why.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: Jesus Christ, Michael, then let's hit 'em now, while we still got the muscle.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: This was my father's old study. When I was a kid, we had to be quiet when we played near here. When I was older, I learned many things from him here.  I was happy that this house never went to strangers; first Clemenza took it over, and then you.  My father taught me, in this room, never to act until you know everything that's behind things.  Never.  If Hyman Roth sees that I interceded with you in the Rosato Brothers' favor, he'll think his relationship with me is still sound.  I'm going somewhere to meet him tomorrow.  We have friends in some very important business that we're making.  Do this for me; you make the peace with the Rosato Brothers on their terms.  Let the word out that I forced you; you're not happy wit hit, but acquiesced, just because of me.  It will get back to Hyman Roth.  Do this, Frankie.  You can trust me.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: Sure, Mike.  I'll go along.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: neri
Dialogue: Fifteen percent skim?

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Twenty-five this time.

Speaker: neri
Dialogue: It might show.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Mike wants it.

Speaker: neri
Dialogue: We've never sent this much with one courier.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: And it's got to be there by Monday morning, no slip-up.

Speaker: courier
Dialogue: I think I was 'picked-up' last trip. That hour layover I had at Kennedy. I went over and bought a paper...

Speaker: neri
Dialogue: Those were our people.

Speaker: courier
Dialogue: Okay, just thought you should know.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Let them count.

Speaker: neri
Dialogue: What's up?

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: No questions.

Speaker: neri
Dialogue: I got to ask questions, Tom, there's three million dollars cash in that pouch; Mike is gone and I have no word from him.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Al, as far as you're concerned, I'm the Don.

Speaker: neri
Dialogue: How do I know you haven't gone into business for yourself?

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: You've been through a lot with us so I'm going to give you the truth. Mike knows it was someone within the compound that set him up for that hit.  So nobody is to know where he is, not you, not Rocco, not even his brother Fredo.  Sorry, Al, I know how you feel about Mike...but he still remembers Tessio.

Speaker: theresa
Dialogue: Hungry?

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Just a little.

Speaker: theresa
Dialogue: I've invited Mama, Sandra and the kids for barbecue.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: What about Kay?

Speaker: theresa
Dialogue: I couldn't find her.  She's been so broody, sticks to herself.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Let me try Kay.

Speaker: hagen's son
Dialogue: Hey, Pop, heads up!

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Kay?

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Anyone hungry?

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Hello?

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: What do you mean gone?

Speaker: sandra
Dialogue: The Barretts from Rubicon Bay came by in a new speedboat.  Rocco tried to say she wasn't in, but Kay spotted them and asked if they would take her and the kids for a ride.  That was three hours ago.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Why didn't someone tell me!

Speaker: sandra
Dialogue: I wanted to tell you alone; your wife doesn't know what's going on.

Speaker: hagen's son
Dialogue: Hey, Dad!

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Rocco!

Speaker: rocco
Dialogue: I know.  I went down to the Barrett house.  But she's gone.  They drove her and the kids to North Tahoe airport.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Goddamn it, where were you?

Speaker: rocco
Dialogue: I was in my house.  Willy tried, but it would have taken some strong-arm to stop her, and he figured you wouldn't want that.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Get me a Scotch and water.

Speaker: rocco
Dialogue: She took a flight to San Francisco. We figure she's going to connect to New Hampshire; her parents' place.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: I can't let him down.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: All right, let me think a minute.

Speaker: rocco
Dialogue: Me too, Tom?

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Yeah, give me a minute.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Oh Christ, Pop.  It was so good when you were alive.  I felt I could handle anything...

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Habana, Habana.

Speaker: sam roth
Dialogue: Hiya, Mr. Corleone, I'm Sam Roth. Welcome to the Capri; my brother's upstairs.  You wanta take a rest before you see him, or can I get you something, anything at all?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: No, I'm fine.

Speaker: sam roth
Dialogue: This is it!  We think it makes Vegas look like the corner crap game.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Very impressive.

Speaker: sam roth
Dialogue: Jake, Jake, come over here.  Mike, I want you to meet Jake Cohen; he manages the casino for us.

Speaker: cohen
Dialogue: Mr. Corleone.

Speaker: sam roth
Dialogue: Pleasure to meet you, I'm sure...

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: Most respected gentlemen, allow me to welcome you to the City of Havana, the Republic of Cuba on behalf of His Excellency, Fulgencio Batista.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: The President would like to take this opportunity to thank U T&T for their lovely gift: a solid gold telephone!  He thought all you gentlemen would care to take a look at it.

Speaker: corngold
Dialogue: Your Excellency, perhaps you could discuss the status of rebel activity and how this may affect our businesses.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: We began a highly successful offensive against them in March, and activities within the city itself are at a minimum.  I can assure you we'll tolerate no guerrillas in the casinos or swimming pools!

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: He says it will just be a short time and they'll let us through.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Cuba Libres.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I was told the Cubans now call this drink: "La Mentira."

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: I still don't speak Spanish, Michael.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: It means... "The Lie."

Speaker: sam roth
Dialogue: The cake is here.

Speaker: everyone
Dialogue: Happy Birthday!

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: I hope my age is correct: I am always accurate about my age.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Everything we've learned in Vegas is true here; but we can go further. The bigger, the swankier, the plusher the store, the more a sense of legitimacy, and the bigger business we do.  Thank you.  We can find people in the United States who will put up our share for a small piece of the action, yet we will retain control.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: A hundred million dollars.  But only if this Government relaxes its restrictions on importing building materials; we'll need some new laws, too, but that will be no difficulty.

Speaker: another man
Dialogue: What are import duties now?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: As much as seventy percent.  Also, I'm working out an arrangement with the Minister of Labor so that all our pit bosses, stick-men and Dealers, can be considered specialized technicians eligible for two year visas.  As of now they're only allowed in Cuba for six months at a time.  In short, we're in a full partnership with the Cuban Government.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Here are applications from Friends all over the States.  I understand Santo Virgilio in Tampa is trying to make his own deal.  Well, the Cuban Government will brush him off. The Lakeville Road Boys are going to take over the Nacionale here. I'm planning a new hotel casino to be known as Riviera.  The new Capri will go to the Corleone Family.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Then there's the Sevilla Biltmore; the Havana Hilton, which is going to cost twenty-four million -- Cuban banks will put up half, the Teamsters will bankroll the rest. Generally, there will be friends for all our friends including the Lieutenant Governor of Nevada; Eddie Levine of Newport will bring in the Pennino Brothers, Dino and Eddie; they'll handle actual casino operations.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Enjoy.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I saw an interesting thing today. A man was being arrested by the Military Police; probably an urban guerrilla.  Rather than be taken alive, he exploded a grenade hidden in his jacket, taking the command vehicle with him.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: It occurred to me: the police are paid to fight, and the Rebels are not.

Speaker: sam roth
Dialogue: So?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: So, that occurred to me.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: This country has had rebels for the last fifty years; it's part of their blood.  Believe me, I know... I've been coming here since the twenties; we were running molasses out of Havana when you were a baby. To trucks owned by your father.  We'll talk when we're alone.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: You have to be careful what you say in front of the others... they frighten easy.  It's always been that way, most men frighten easy.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: We're making a big investment in Cuba.  That's my only concern.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: My concern is that the three million never arrived at Batista's numbered account in Switzerland. He thinks it's because you have second thoughts about his ability to stop the rebels.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: The money was sent.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Then you have to trace it.  Michael, people here look at me as a reliable man.  I can't afford not to be looked on as a reliable man.  But you know all that; there's nothing you can learn from me.  You shouldn't have to put up with a sick old man as a partner.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I wouldn't consider anyone else.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Except the President of the United States.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: If only I could live to see it, kid; to be there with you.  How beautifully we've done it, step by step.  Here, protected, free to make our profits without the Justice Department, the FBI; ninety miles away in partnership with a friendly government.  Ninety miles, just a small step, looking for a man who desperately wants to be President of the United States, and having the cash to make it possible.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: You'll be there to see it; you'll be there.

Speaker: operator
Dialogue: We have your call to Tahoe, Nevada, sir.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Thank you.  Tom?  Tom, is that you?

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: I'm not surprised to see you, Tom.

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: He's not like a little boy... he doesn't talk to me; he doesn't want to play; he doesn't like other children, he doesn't like toys. It's as though he's waiting for the time he can take his Father's place.  You know what he told me when he was four years old.  He said he had killed his Grandfather...

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: ... He said he had shot his Grandfather with a gun, and then he died in the garden.  And he asked me... he asked me, Tom, if that meant now his father would shoot him out of... revenge.  How does a four year old boy learn the word... 'revenge'?

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Kay... Kay...

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: What kind of a family is this... are we human beings?  He knows his Father killed his Uncle Carlo.  He heard Connie.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: You don't know that's true.  But Kay, just for the sake of an argument, let's assume it is, I'm not saying it is, remember, but... What if I gave you what might be some justification for what he did... or rather some possible justification for what he possibly did.

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: That's the first time I've seen the lawyer side of you, Tom.  It's not your best side.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: Okay, just hear me out.  What if Carlo had been paid to help get Sonny killed?  What if his beating of Connie that time was a deliberate plot to get Sonny out into the open? Then what?  And what if the Don, a great man, couldn't bring himself to do what he had to do, avenge his son's death by killing his daughter's husband?  What if that, finally, was too much for him, and he made Michael his successor, knowing that Michael would take that load off his shoulders, would take that guilt?

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: He's not the same as when I met him.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: If he were, he'd be dead by now. You'd be a widow.  You'd have no problem.

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: What the hell does that mean?  Come on, Tom, speak out straight once in your life.  I know Michael can't, but you're not Sicilian, you can tell a woman the truth; you can treat her like an equal, a fellow human being.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: If you told Michael what I've told you today, I'm a dead man.

Speaker: kay
Dialogue: When is it finally over?  I want it to be over before my baby is born.

Speaker: hagen
Dialogue: I don't know.  I hope soon; but it's not over yet, and that's why you and the kids have to come back to me.

Speaker: loudspeaker
Dialogue: Mr. Corleone; Mr. Freddie Corleone, telephone please.

Speaker: pit boss
Dialogue: Not here.

Speaker: loudspeaker
Dialogue: Telephone for Mr. Corleone.

Speaker: neri
Dialogue: He's backstage.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: C'mon, you got fifteen minutes before the finale!  I want to show you a trick with feathers.

Speaker: stagehand
Dialogue: Phone for you.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Don't go away; wait a minute.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Sure... how much?  I understand. Jesus, three million... I won't let you down.  Sure.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Yeah... some other time.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: Wait in the car.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: What's this?

Speaker: rosato
Dialogue: That's a lucky C note for our new deal.

Speaker: rosato
Dialogue: We were all real happy about your decision, Frankie; you're not goin' to regret it.

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: I don't like the C-note.  I take it like an insult.

Speaker: rosato
Dialogue: Shit, your friend the cop!

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Everything all right in there, Ritchie?  The door was open.

Speaker: ritchie
Dialogue: Just cleaning up.  You okay?

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Is that something on the floor?

Speaker: rosato
Dialogue: Take him!

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: ritchie
Dialogue: Not here; not a cop, not here!

Speaker: cop
Dialogue: Stutz!  Watch out, Stutz!

Speaker: pentangeli
Dialogue: The bastard.  The dirty bastard, he gave me a C-note.  He gave me a C- note.

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: Frankie Pentangeli murder attempt. Patrolman Stutz shot.  Sahara Lounge - Utica Avenue and Claredon Road.  White Cadillac three or four men took off from scene.  Need ambulance; Stutz is bad.  Taking Pentangeli into custody...

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Make it fast; I don't want to chance him being seen.

Speaker: courier
Dialogue: What about the arrangements?  How can I be sure about the arrangements?

Speaker: ola
Dialogue: Relax.  You're under our protection; the Corleone family will never find you.

Speaker: courier
Dialogue: Hey, what's this?

Speaker: courier
Dialogue: The arrangements... YOU BASTARDS! What...

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Mikey.  How are you?

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Hiya, Freddie Corleone.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Mio fratello.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: What a trip, Jesus Christ, the whole time I'm thinking what if someone knew what I got in here.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Oh, 'scuse me.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: It's all right.  He stays with me all the time.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Oh.  Mikey, what's up?  I'm totally in the dark.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: We're making an investment in Havana.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Great, Havana's great.  Lots of activity in Havana!  Anybody I know here.  Five-Angels?  Anybody?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Johnny Ola... Hyman Roth.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: I never met them.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Pentangeli's dead.  He was ambushed by the Rosato Brothers.  Didn't you know that?

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: No.  No, I didn't.  Who tells me anything?  I been kept in the dark so long, I'm getting used to it.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I want you to help me, Fredo.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: That's what I'm here for.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Tonight I want to relax with you. The Senator from Nevada is here with some people from Washington. I want to show them a good time in Havana.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Count on me; that's my specialty.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I'd like to come along.  There's been a lot of strain, and I've been cooped up in this room for three days.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Me and you, great!  Gimme an hour to wash my face and do my research and we'll have these Washington suckers right where you want 'em.  Poor Frankie Five-Angels.  He always wanted to die in bed...with a broad.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: You must not exert yourself; I will write out a prescription and come back tomorrow.

Speaker: hotel man
Dialogue: He's going to write a prescription.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: I want my own doctor; fly him in from Miami.  I don't trust a doctor who can't speak English.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Honey, go down to the casino?

Speaker: terri
Dialogue: If you feel better...

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: I do.  Play the Bingo game.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: My sixth sense tells me you have a bag full of money in your hand.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: This doubles my investment.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Still no word of your courier? We'll find him.  But at least this will satisfy our friends here. You've been invited to the New Year reception at the Presidential Home. I understand your brother is here as well; I hope he'll come.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Six million dollars in cash is a high price for a piece of a country in the middle of a revolution.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: You're a careful kid, and that's good.  But look.  An international dispatch on the wire service. American journalism, not propaganda. The government troops have all but eliminated the rebels.  All but their radio station.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I've read it; I'm pleased that the government is doing so well.  As a heavy investor, I'm pleased.  How did the doctor find you?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Terrible.  I'd give twice this amount to take a piss without it hurting.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Who had Frankie Pantangeli killed?

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: Why...the Rosato Brothers.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I know that; but who gave the go ahead.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I know it wasn't me...so that leaves you.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: There was this kid that I grew up with; he was a couple years younger than me, and sort of looked up to me, you know.  We did our first work together, worked our way out of the street.  Things were good and we made the most of it.  During prohibition, we ran molasses up to Canada and made a fortune; your father too.  I guess as much as anyone, I loved him and trusted him. Later on he had an idea to make a city out of a desert stop-over for G.I.'s on the way to the West Coast. That kid's name was Moe Greene, and the city he invented was Las Vegas. This was a great man; a man with vision and guts; and there isn't even a plaque or a signpost or a statue of him in that town.  Someone put a bullet through his eye; no one knows who gave the order.  When I heard about it I wasn't angry.  I knew Moe; I knew he was headstrong, and talking loud, and saying stupid things.  So when he turned up dead, I let it go, and said to myself: this is the business we've chosen. I never asked, who gave the go ahead because it had nothing to do with business.

Speaker: roth
Dialogue: There's three million dollars on that table.  I'm going to lie down, maybe take a nap.  When I wake up, if it's still there, I'll know I have a partner.  If it's gone, then I'll know I don't.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: How sick do you think the old man is?

Speaker: bussetta
Dialogue: He'll live longer than me.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Does everyone know everyone, or nobody knows nobody.  Here, my brother, Michael Corleone... well, you know Senator Geary.

Speaker: senator geary
Dialogue: Good to see you, Mike; I'm glad we can spend this time together.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: This is Senator Payton from Florida; Judge DeMalco from New York... Senator Ream... Mr. Questadt from California, he's a lawyer with the Price-Control Administration.  And Fred Corngold of U T&T.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Gentlemen... your pleasure?  Cuba Libres, Pina Coladas, you name it.

Speaker: senator geary
Dialogue: I'll take a Yolanda.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Later, later.  All those girls look like they're on stilts!

Speaker: senator geary
Dialogue: To a night in Havana!

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Jeeze, it's great you came along, Mike... You know, we've never spent a night out on the town together. I always thought you looked down on me for liking a good time.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I never looked down on you, Fredo. You don't look down at a brother.

Speaker: corngold
Dialogue: Our information is that Castro is dead.  There are maybe a few hundred die-hards in the Sierra Muestra; but government troops are going to clean them out any day.

Speaker: ola
Dialogue: Mike, can I talk to you.

Speaker: ola
Dialogue: Listen, this Senator from Florida already has a hundred grand worth of markers on the table.

Speaker: ola
Dialogue: They asked him to sign paper to take down the markers; but he got mad; told them to wait until he was finished.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Let him gamble.

Speaker: ola
Dialogue: Okay.  You know he doesn't have that kind of money.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Mike said let him gamble.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Mike, I got something special up my sleeve for these boys.  You ever hear of "Superman?" And I don't mean the comic book.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Wait'll you see!

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Mikey, why would they ever hit poor old Frankie Five-Angels?  I loved that ole sonuvabitch.  I remember when he was just a 'button,' when we were kids.  We used to put bedsheets on our heads, you know, like we were ghosts.  An' ole Frankie come peek into our room, we'd jump up, and he'd always pretend like he was really scared. You remember?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: It was hard to have him killed.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: You?  What do you mean you, I thought...

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: It was hard to have him killed.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: You?  What do you mean you, I thought...

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: It was Frankie tried to have me hit.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: No.  I mean, are you sure?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: You know otherwise, Freddie?

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Me?  NO, no, I don't know anything. Fellas!  You're all falling asleep. We got to see Superman.

Speaker: senator ream
Dialogue: Goddamn beggers.  Goddamn city of beggars and pimps and whores.  And we bend over backwards to support them with the goddamn sugar quota.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: What's eating him?

Speaker: senator geary
Dialogue: He lost a quarter million dollars at the casino.

Speaker: senator ream
Dialogue: ...goddamn city of whores...

Speaker: senator geary
Dialogue: He gave them a bad check.

Speaker: questadt
Dialogue: Why do we have to stand?

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Everyone stands.  But it's worth it, watch!

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: That's him; that's Superman!

Speaker: senator geary
Dialogue: Ohmygod.  I don't believe it.

Speaker: questadt
Dialogue: It's got to be fake.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: That's why they call him Superman. Johnny Ola told me about this; I didn't believe it.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: The old man Roth, would never come; but Johnny knows these places like the back of his hand...

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: "This is Rebel Radio: Rebel troops of Column Four 'Jose Marti' took the town of Baire yesterday at 8:30 p.m.  The enemy has retreated..."

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: ... An important military action is developing along a 35-kilometer stretch of the Central Highway. Numerous enemy garrisons are left with two alternatives, surrender or annihilation...

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: ... Victories in war depend on a minimum on weapons and to a maximum on morale...

Speaker: radio
Dialogue: ... War is not a simple question of rifles, bullets, guns and planes...

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: How is your wife, Fredo...your marriage?

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: You know her; drives me crazy, one minute she's a popsicle, the next she's all vinegar.  Sometimes I think... I think - I should a married someone, like you did.  To have kids, to have a family.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: "Yo soy un hombre sincero..." I am a sincere man, From the land of the palms...

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: The song.  Are you sincere with me, Fredo?

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Sincere.  What are you talking about, of course I'm sincere with you, Mike.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Then I'm going to confide in you; trust you with something.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Mike, are you crazy, I'm your brother.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Tonight we've been invited to a reception at the Presidential Palace; to bring in the New Year. You and I will go in a special car that's being sent.  They'll have cocktails... then dinner, and a reception with the President.  When it's over, it will be suggested that you take Questadt and his friends from Washington to spend the night with some women.  I'll go home alone in the car; and before I reach the hotel, I'll be assassinated.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: ...Who?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: The same man who tried in Nevada... Hyman Roth, not Pentangeli.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: But, you told me yourself...

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: It was never Pentangeli... I've always known that.  It was Roth all along.  He talks to me as a son; as his successor, but the old man thinks he'll live forever.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: What do you want me to do?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: To go tonight, with me, as though we know nothing.  I've already made my move.

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: What is it?  Can I help?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: The old man will never bring in the New Year.

Speaker: questadt
Dialogue: The embargo on arms shipments from the U.S. to your government, was just a necessary public relations move... Only last month, your air force received a major shipment of rockets...

Speaker: senator geary
Dialogue: We believe in non-intervention... but the agreement stipulates that our forces may be withdrawn... but as you've seen, we have not withdrawn them.

Speaker: corngold
Dialogue: And my guess is that President Eisenhower won't pull out while we have over three billion invested over here.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Fredo.  Where are you going?

Speaker: fredo
Dialogue: Nowhere, Mike.  I wanted to get a refill.  How about you?

Speaker: questadt
Dialogue: What's kept Mr. Roth?

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I've arranged for a plane; we're going to Miami in an hour.  Try not to make a big thing of it.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: I know it was you, Fredo.  You've broken my heart.

Speaker: leon
Dialogue: What a pity; she's crying.  Must have been fired, and she's been with the President's family for twenty years.

Speaker: president
Dialogue: ...Because of serious setbacks of our troops in Guantanamo and Santiago, we feel reluctantly, that we must leave the Capital at once. Myself and my family must bid you goodbye, and good fortune.  We will go directly to Ciudad Trujillo.

Speaker: president
Dialogue: ...My only regret is that there could not have been more warning... As my last official act as President, I hereby appoint a provisional government with Dr. Carlos M. Piedra, as its President.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: Come with me.  It's your only way of getting out!

Speaker: pilot
Dialogue: No, this is a private plane.  No, this plane is taken.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: He isn't here.

Speaker: pilot
Dialogue: We've got to leave, they'll take this thing apart.

Speaker: michael
Dialogue: All right.  Go now.

Speaker: vendor
Dialogue: No, no.  It is my pleasure to make this a gift.

Speaker: vito
Dialogue: You are kind.  If ever I can do something for you, in return, please come to me.

Speaker: vito
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: carmella
Dialogue: Come...

Speaker: carmella
Dialogue: The Signora is a friend of mine. She has a favor to ask of you.

Speaker: vito
Dialogue: Why do you come to me?

Speaker: signora colombo
Dialogue: She told me to ask you.

Speaker: carmella
Dialogue: She is having some trouble.  Her landlord has received complaints because of her dog.  He told her to get rid of it, but her boy loved it, so they tried to hide it.  When the landlord found out, he was so angry, he ordered her to leave. Even if she truly will let the dog go.

Speaker: signora colombo
Dialogue: He said he would have the police put us out.

Speaker: vito
Dialogue: I can give you some money to help you move, is that what you want?

Speaker: signora colombo
Dialogue: My friends are all here; how can I move to another neighborhood with strangers?  I want you to speak to the landlord to let me stay.

Speaker: vito
